HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 29, 1927

VOL. XXXII, No. 16

JAY CROSS COUNTRY
TEAM BEATS TERPS
Jay Harriers Close Successful
Season
GWINN AGAIN SETS MARK

SOPHS TO HOLD
MEETING TOMORROW
Tommorw at 12:30 the
sophomore class will hold a
meeting in the C. E. Hall. At
the meeting plans for the class
rush Saturday will be formulated. Purnell Hall, the class
president, urges all sophomores to be present.

Schiebel and Kelley Run Second
and Third Respectively

Foreign Students
Attend Dinner
banners

Victory perched on the
of the Jay cross-country team as
Hopkins defeated the University
of Maryland, 27 to --30, in one of the
most dramatic runs ever seen here.
Dick Gwinn, stellar Jay runne;
finished his career in a blaze of
glory. Both he and Herman Schiebel broke all previous- records for
the course, taking first and second
Places for the Black and Blue.
Third place went to Hopkins also,
being annexed by Bob Kelley.
Fourth to eighth places went to
the College Parkers, who ran a
steady, but not brilliant race. The
heart-breaking sharp ups and downs
of the Hopkins course, perhaps the
hardest of any in the State, spelled
defeat for the hard-trying Marylanders.
The first three places were never
in doubt. Gwinn, Schiebel and Kelley took the lead and drew steadily
away from the field. Even on the
first lap they were far ahead. At
the finish Gwinn was over 500 yards
ahead of the nearest Terrapin runner.
Wheeler Ninth

Wheeler, running on a badly hurt
ankle, sprained in the Navy meet a
few weeks ago, took fourth place
for Hopkins, coming— in ninth. Emerson, a freshman, scored fifth,
coming in twelfth.
The standing record for the
/
4 mile cross-country
Homewood 43
was held by Gwinn, who made it in
23 min. 25 sec. in 1926. Gwinn
bettered his previous time by 26
seconds, making it in 22 min. 59
sec. Schiebel also broke the record
by 11 seconds, finishing in 23 min.
15 sec. Kelley's time was 23 min.
53 sec., while the first Maryland
man, Myers, took 2 min. 22 sec.
NlYers, Gadd, Plumley, Schrieber
and Lindsey scored for the visitors.
The first five men finishing in each
team are counted in the score. The
first counts one, second place two,
and so forth. The lowest score
wins. Hopkins took first, second,
third, ninth and twelfth, making a
total of 27. The Maryland harriers
took fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh
and eighth, making a total of 30
Points.
Moryland Consistent

That Maryland had a consistent
team was known, and the fact that
the score was so close gives evidence to the fact of its value, but
that they should have had their men
bunched for five consecutive places
was very unusual. Coach Ridgely
Edwards said "this is the most peculiar score I have ever seen made."
Many football fans viewing the
Loyola College-Mt. St. Mary's footall game stopped to look at the
finish of the cross-country race.
Due to the fact that the Loyola
game was being held on the upper

Ninety-nine students from twenty
foreign countries attended a Thanksgiving dinner under the auspices
of the Intercollegiate Young Men's
Christian Association at the Central
Y. M. C. A. Wednesday night.
Mr. P. S. Maker, a native of
India, criticized the United States'
attitude towards conditions in
China, claiming that the sending of
warships to that country is in direct
opposition to the ideals of the Pilo-rims.
Other speakers of the evening
were Dr. John C. French, University Librarian; Egbert Hayes of
China; Carleton Harrison, general
secretary of the local branch of the
Y. M. C. A., and R. L. Carey of
The Baltimore Sun.
Mr. E. A. Schaal presided, introducing the various speakers.

Rushing Agreement IN
a Not Violated This Year
For the first time in the history
of • the Inter-fraternity Board, no
disputes or controversies arose after
pledge day. At the meeting of the
Board last week, the rushing agreement escaped adverse criticism completely. President Warfield and
other members of the Board expressed the opinion that the agreement was a great success.
Last week-end the National Interfraternity Board Conference was
held in New York City. No delegate from the Hopkins Board attended this conference, for by unanimous vote of the Board, it was decided that the expenses exceeded
the profits derived from the trip.
However, a motion was made that
Hopkins be represented at least by
a letter.
In view of the fact that no business is expected to arise for some
time,.there will be no more Board
meetings until after the Christmas
recess.

FROSH TRACK TEAM
BLOCKING
DOWNS SOPHOMORES
Lockard and Yellott Prove Big
Factors in Yearlings' 54-26
Triumph Over Sophs
Freshmen athletes pranced around
the track Tuesday, easily defeating
the sophomores by a 54-26 score, in
the first of the annual clashes between the two lower classes.
The meet, which attracted little
interest from either side, was held
on the Homewood Field track and
dragged on until after dark. Coach
Ridgely Edwards of the Hopkins
track team, assisted by Charles W.
McElfresh, varsity manager, and
veteran Jay runners, conducted the
•
meet.
Victory No Surprise

The yearlings' victory came a,
no surprise, because pre-meet information had favored the wearers
of the green ties.
As far as individual performance
is concerned, the honors of the day
must be awarded to Eddie Lockard, former track star of Forest
Park igh SHchool, and Yellott, who
had the unique distinction of turning in two first places each for their
classes. Lockard led the field in
the 100 yard and the 220 yard
events, nad Yellott did the same in
the 440 and 880.
The frosh succeeded in capturing
seven first places out of nine contests, thereby securing thirty-five of
their points. In' the 110 yard run,
only freshmen were entered, and
the 880, the lone sophomore of the
three men starting, dropped out of
the running, leaving the yearlings
the first two places.
The sophomores outclassed the
freshmen in only two events, the
high jump and the shotput. The
former was won by Ruark, by topping the bar at a height of four
feet and nine inches. The only
contestants in the shot put were
sophs, of whom Wrightson, Heim
and Beeuwkes scored the first three
places, respectively.
Paserew, a freshman, showed the
way in the mile run, Lang, '30, finishing second with another freshman, Miller, finishing third to add
another point for the victorious
frosh.
In the 100 yard dash, Lockard
was followed by a sophomore,

CROWD OF VARSITY CLUB ALUMNI
ATTEND PRE-GAME PEP RALLY
Enthusiastic Varsity Club alumni
filled the C. E. Hall to capacity
Thanksgiving Eve for a pre-game
rally. The party had been long
projected as a final get-together of
the Club.
Everybody was there from Goodwin of the Class of '80 through
the years to '28. They enjoyed
themselves, too. And the cheers
rocked the building—really hearty
cheers—cheers and songs of old
opkins, some of them unfamiliar
to freshman ears; but sung
with a real warmth of feeling, due
partly to the refreshments, and partly to that old college spirit that
makes the old grad come back year
after year and "give all he has" for
the Black and Blue.
Dave Kaufman was chairman of
the affair, while Fred Bauernschmidt
officiated as toastmaster. Dr. Ray
Van Orman, Henry Iddins and
Doug Turnbull, Captain of the '25
team, gave short talks amid wild

applause. Oh, it was a "jolly good
time." Pop Swindell sang a rather
appropriate verse on Lager Beer
and carried on with the customary
dramatics. And did Hopkins "rise
to the utmost heights ?" Well, look
at the score next day.
Jake Miller of '22, slightly under
the weather and hunting for a
"short fellow who called him
names," was called upon by popular
demand to give his little contribution to the evening. Warfield and
the other cheer leaders led the
cheering to the accompaniment of
one, or possibly two, fingered "seek
and find" on the piano.
But all things come to an end
and even Varsity Club parties are
no exception. After frenzied class
yells, the classes of '20 up being
most represented, the members went
home—presumably.
This smoker was begun last year
and it will be held as an annual
affair on the night before the Maryland game each year.

OF KESSLERS' KICK
RESULTS IN JAY VICTORY

JAYS LOSE EIGHT
BY GRADUATION
Eight of the Jay gridders
who played in the Maryland
game have participated in their
last football game at Hopkins.
With the exception of Kegan,
the entire line will be lost by
graduation at the end of this
year. Lawrence and Pindell
of the backfield also will not
return to the University.
Maryland, on the other
hand, will lose only five regulars. Adams, Zulich, Thomas,
Linkous and Captain Bafford
will not return to College
Park next year. Augie Roberts, who played a sensational
game at halfback, still has two
more years of college football.

0. K. D. to Announce
Pledges Thursday
Honorary Activities Society To Take
Charge of Assembly

Omicron Delta Kappa will take
charge of this Thursday's assembly.
The student body will witness the
public initiation of the flew men
chosen at the fall elections this year.
Dean Joseph S. Ames will be the
principal speaker. In the eve" ,g
the customary private initiation and
banquet will be held at the Southern Hotel. Walter B. Swindell, Jr.,
will preside as toast-master.
0. D. K. is a national honor society for men who distinguish themselves in the various branches of
college activities. It is a means of
recognition and reward for those
who have given unsparingly of their
time and effort and who have benefited the university. I. Evans Rodgers is president this year.

Jack Lawrence Scores Both
Hopkins Touchdowns
In First Half
CAPLAN MAKES POINTS
Byrd Tries Notre Damentunt
Of Starting Second
String Team
Johns Hopkins came into its own
last Thursday when the University
of Maryland was ,beaten, 14 to 13.
During most of the second half it
seemed that last year's heart-breaking defeat was to be duplicated, but
when Kessler, Maryland's quarter,
attempted to drop-kick the point
after the Terrapins' second touchdown, Dave Kaufman and Dal
Strader opened a hole in the right
side of the line and. stellar Benny
Boynton tore through and cornered
the ball before it had gone three feet
from Kess1er's toe. With a onepoint lead the Blue team braced up
and held its own until the last half
of the fourth quarter, when it called
upon an unlooked-for and almost
an undreamed-of reserve strength,
which resulted in a drive down the
field to the Terrapins' four-yard
line. Just as the stands were sensing another score, the whistle blew,
the game was ended and Hopkins
had achieved what had been its goal
for twelve years.

Harvard has challenged Yale to
a "battle of culture," thus inaugurating something new in the field of
intercollegiate activity. Harvard
suggests the meeting of teams of
ten men before a body of judges,
to contest the superiority of college
men in the realms of the erudite.
In order to obviate all chance of
t'cramming" before such a contest,
the ten men cannot be licked until
very shortly before the time the
teams meet. If this idea survives
the ridicule it is bound to receive,
Harvard will have launched a
Worthy movement toward making
• colleges further fulfill their original
purpose.
*

The idea of the waste of a college education, as talked about by
our eminent Dr. Mitchell some time
ago, seems to be very contagious.
Grbizt W. Van Salm, super-intellectual at Lafayette and winner of
many oratorical pri,s'es; asks the Lafayette undergraduates in a recent
assembly: "College! - What's the
Use?" He puts his answer much
more mildly than the fiery Dr.
Mitchell. "College did nothing
more than waste four years of my
life." And yet, college enrollments
are growing everywhere. What
silly sots are we poor collegians!

John Van Druten, who produced
a Play at the Playshop last year,
recently delivered a lecture at Lafayette on "Making a Play." This
noted English playwright was received at Lafayette bjran enthusiastic group, and lectured to a very
large audience. He spoke of the
new ideas and technique of writing
Plays, and many other interesting
features of the playwright's life.
Van Druten's personality and interesting topic won for him the praise
of Lafayette's dramatists, just as he
wan praise here last year.
* * * * *
Two students at the City College of New York have been suspended indefinitely for agitation
.against compulsory military training. Military training at this college has been a disputed quesfon
for a number of years. A vote
taken two years ago; following extraordinarv agitation, showed the
students to be against the compulsory training by a tremendous malority. Parents of the boys were
also greatly against it. Then for
two years no more was heard on
the subject. But now, another crisis
has come. Why not, as the Daily
:rincetonian advocates in reviewing the situation, "make military
training a non-compulsory course?"
Certainly, it works pretty well here
at Hopkins.

HOPKINS HOLDS EARLY LEAD TO
DEFEAT MARYLAND BY ONE POINT

M

(Continued from page 1, column 5.)

land exchanged the kick and after
two passes, Lyons to Boynton and
then to Caplan, the b01 was on the
5-yard line. A third_ pass was
grounded over the goal line and
the ball was brought out to Maryland's 20-yard line.
Another exchange of punts, a
few line plays and the quarter ended
with the ball in Hopkins' possession. Score at end of quarter: Hopkins 7—Maryland 0.
The second quarter began with
Hopkins completing two passes; the
second a long one to Captain Mallonee which put the ball on Maryland's 8 yard line. Two line plays
and Lawrence dived across .the goal
for the second score. Again Caplan booted the ball over the bar,
with the splendid co-operafon of
Lyons, for the extra point.
Roberts Nearly Scores

Maryland received the kick-off
and Roberts, Terrapin back-field
star, then proceeded to furnish one
of the most thrilling incidents of
the game when, with almost perfect
interference, he broke away and
looked as though he would make a
touchdown until he was finally
brought down by Mallonee and
Lyons.
The game see-sawed back and
forth, neither team having much
the better of it except in the k!cking department, where every exchange of punts netted Hopkins
anywhere from 5 to 20 yards. The
half, an all-Hopkins half, ended
with the score: Hopkins 14—Maryland 0.
What "Curly" Byrd lacked in
generalship in sending his second
team on the field to be scored upon
so easily in the first quarter and
then having his nervous and cold
first-string men fa:1 to stop the
swift-moving Hopkins machine, he
almost made up by injecting a marvelous amount of fight into his
players during the rest between
halves, for the third quarter was as
much an "all-Maryland" affair as
the first half had been an all-Hopkins one.

Esso

Maryland ran through the line,
around the end and heaved passes
until they took the ball over for
their first score. Kessler dropkicked the extra point. After the
first taste of blood Maryland was
not to be stopped, and after two
first downs a pass netted the Terrapins 20 yards and put the ball on
the Jays' 22-yard line. Another
first down and the quarter was over,
with the ball on Hopkins' 3-yard
line. Score at end of third quarter,
Hopkins 14—Maryland 7.
Two plays were all that were
needed to take the ball the necessary 3 yards, but when Kessler went
back to kick, the ball had hardly
left his toe before Boynton, who
had replaced Pindell in the backfield, Houston filling his place at
end, was on him and the ball was
grounded. From that point on
Hopkins began to play better and
better, so that by the end of the
game the ball was on Maryland's
4 yard line.
The game was a victory of one
wonderfully playing team over another. Neither team lost one ounce
of fight—it was just Hopkins' day
and the Big Blue team seized its
opportunity to win a glorious victory.

1927 JUNE WEEK
DEFICIT MADE UP
The 1927 June Week Committee has made up its deficit.
The money cleared on the
dance at the Maryland Casualty after the Maryland-Hopkins game made up the needed
money and more besides. Total
gate receipts to date are
$765.20. That means that
there were 380 couples present. The expenses for the hall
and orchestra amounted to
$250, leaving a balance of
$515.20. The committee owed
the University a note of $401.
The money made on the dance
paid that off and left a remainder of $114.20, which will
be turned over to the Student
Activities Council.

Large Crowd Expected To Attend
Frosh-Soph Battle.

Four more days will decide
whether or not the freshmen don
their regalia until Christmas.
Thursday they clash with the sophomores in lacrosse and Saturday
in football and class rush.
In lacrosse a few freshmen have
been practicing faithfully, under the
leadersh:p of Norman Robinson,
ex-captain of the Blue Jay stickwielders, for several weeks.
As this is the first year that lacrosse has been substituted for
baseball, there should be a crowd
to witness the inauguration of this
sport as a freshman-sophomore contest.
Saturday's scrimmage should
abound in thrills. Sadder and
wiser after their first two defeats,
the frosh are determined to beat
the sophs, in spite of the fact that
the latter team has continually won
in the past.
Sophomore football equipment
was distributed yesterday. George
Darley, who is coaching the secondyear men, s endeavoring to mould
a shifty eleven.
Robinson will officiate at the la—
crosse match, while Mallonee will
officiate at the football game. As
the.frosh have won the track meet,
one more victory for them will
cause the abolishment of green ties,
black socks and frosh buttons.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 29, 1927

VOL. XXXII, No. 16

JAY CROSS COUNTRY
TEAM BEATS TERPS
Jay Harriers Close Successful
Season
GWINN AGAIN SETS MARK

SOPHS TO HOLD
MEETING TOMORROW
Tommorw at 12:30 the
sophomore class will hold a
meeting in the C. E. Hall. At
the meeting plans for the class
rush Saturday will be formulated. Purnell Hall, the class
president, urges all sophomores to be present.

Schiebel and Kelley Run Second
and Third Respectively

Foreign Students
Attend Dinner
banners

Victory perched on the
of the Jay cross-country team as
Hopkins defeated the University
of Maryland, 27 to --30, in one of the
most dramatic runs ever seen here.
Dick Gwinn, stellar Jay runne;
finished his career in a blaze of
glory. Both he and Herman Schiebel broke all previous- records for
the course, taking first and second
Places for the Black and Blue.
Third place went to Hopkins also,
being annexed by Bob Kelley.
Fourth to eighth places went to
the College Parkers, who ran a
steady, but not brilliant race. The
heart-breaking sharp ups and downs
of the Hopkins course, perhaps the
hardest of any in the State, spelled
defeat for the hard-trying Marylanders.
The first three places were never
in doubt. Gwinn, Schiebel and Kelley took the lead and drew steadily
away from the field. Even on the
first lap they were far ahead. At
the finish Gwinn was over 500 yards
ahead of the nearest Terrapin runner.
Wheeler Ninth

Wheeler, running on a badly hurt
ankle, sprained in the Navy meet a
few weeks ago, took fourth place
for Hopkins, coming— in ninth. Emerson, a freshman, scored fifth,
coming in twelfth.
The standing record for the
/
4 mile cross-country
Homewood 43
was held by Gwinn, who made it in
23 min. 25 sec. in 1926. Gwinn
bettered his previous time by 26
seconds, making it in 22 min. 59
sec. Schiebel also broke the record
by 11 seconds, finishing in 23 min.
15 sec. Kelley's time was 23 min.
53 sec., while the first Maryland
man, Myers, took 2 min. 22 sec.
NlYers, Gadd, Plumley, Schrieber
and Lindsey scored for the visitors.
The first five men finishing in each
team are counted in the score. The
first counts one, second place two,
and so forth. The lowest score
wins. Hopkins took first, second,
third, ninth and twelfth, making a
total of 27. The Maryland harriers
took fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh
and eighth, making a total of 30
Points.
Moryland Consistent

That Maryland had a consistent
team was known, and the fact that
the score was so close gives evidence to the fact of its value, but
that they should have had their men
bunched for five consecutive places
was very unusual. Coach Ridgely
Edwards said "this is the most peculiar score I have ever seen made."
Many football fans viewing the
Loyola College-Mt. St. Mary's footall game stopped to look at the
finish of the cross-country race.
Due to the fact that the Loyola
game was being held on the upper
(Continued on Page 2, Column 2)

Ninety-nine students from twenty
foreign countries attended a Thanksgiving dinner under the auspices
of the Intercollegiate Young Men's
Christian Association at the Central
Y. M. C. A. Wednesday night.
Mr. P. S. Maker, a native of
India, criticized the United States'
attitude towards conditions in
China, claiming that the sending of
warships to that country is in direct
opposition to the ideals of the Pilo-rims.
Other speakers of the evening
were Dr. John C. French, University Librarian; Egbert Hayes of
China; Carleton Harrison, general
secretary of the local branch of the
Y. M. C. A., and R. L. Carey of
The Baltimore Sun.
Mr. E. A. Schaal presided, introducing the various speakers.

Rushing Agreement IN
a Not Violated This Year
For the first time in the history
of • the Inter-fraternity Board, no
disputes or controversies arose after
pledge day. At the meeting of the
Board last week, the rushing agreement escaped adverse criticism completely. President Warfield and
other members of the Board expressed the opinion that the agreement was a great success.
Last week-end the National Interfraternity Board Conference was
held in New York City. No delegate from the Hopkins Board attended this conference, for by unanimous vote of the Board, it was decided that the expenses exceeded
the profits derived from the trip.
However, a motion was made that
Hopkins be represented at least by
a letter.
In view of the fact that no business is expected to arise for some
time,.there will be no more Board
meetings until after the Christmas
recess.

FROSH TRACK TEAM
BLOCKING
DOWNS SOPHOMORES
Lockard and Yellott Prove Big
Factors in Yearlings' 54-26
Triumph Over Sophs
Freshmen athletes pranced around
the track Tuesday, easily defeating
the sophomores by a 54-26 score, in
the first of the annual clashes between the two lower classes.
The meet, which attracted little
interest from either side, was held
on the Homewood Field track and
dragged on until after dark. Coach
Ridgely Edwards of the Hopkins
track team, assisted by Charles W.
McElfresh, varsity manager, and
veteran Jay runners, conducted the
•
meet.
Victory No Surprise

The yearlings' victory came a,
no surprise, because pre-meet information had favored the wearers
of the green ties.
As far as individual performance
is concerned, the honors of the day
must be awarded to Eddie Lockard, former track star of Forest
Park igh SHchool, and Yellott, who
had the unique distinction of turning in two first places each for their
classes. Lockard led the field in
the 100 yard and the 220 yard
events, nad Yellott did the same in
the 440 and 880.
The frosh succeeded in capturing
seven first places out of nine contests, thereby securing thirty-five of
their points. In' the 110 yard run,
only freshmen were entered, and
the 880, the lone sophomore of the
three men starting, dropped out of
the running, leaving the yearlings
the first two places.
The sophomores outclassed the
freshmen in only two events, the
high jump and the shotput. The
former was won by Ruark, by topping the bar at a height of four
feet and nine inches. The only
contestants in the shot put were
sophs, of whom Wrightson, Heim
and Beeuwkes scored the first three
places, respectively.
Paserew, a freshman, showed the
way in the mile run, Lang, '30, finishing second with another freshman, Miller, finishing third to add
another point for the victorious
frosh.
In the 100 yard dash, Lockard
was followed by a sophomore,
Deets, and Neu,'31, who also man(Continued on Page 2, Column 3)

CROWD OF VARSITY CLUB ALUMNI
ATTEND PRE-GAME PEP RALLY
Enthusiastic Varsity Club alumni
filled the C. E. Hall to capacity
Thanksgiving Eve for a pre-game
rally. The party had been long
projected as a final get-together of
the Club.
Everybody was there from Goodwin of the Class of '80 through
the years to '28. They enjoyed
themselves, too. And the cheers
rocked the building—really hearty
cheers—cheers and songs of old
opkins, some of them unfamiliar
to freshman ears; but sung
with a real warmth of feeling, due
partly to the refreshments, and partly to that old college spirit that
makes the old grad come back year
after year and "give all he has" for
the Black and Blue.
Dave Kaufman was chairman of
the affair, while Fred Bauernschmidt
officiated as toastmaster. Dr. Ray
Van Orman, Henry Iddins and
Doug Turnbull, Captain of the '25
team, gave short talks amid wild

applause. Oh, it was a "jolly good
time." Pop Swindell sang a rather
appropriate verse on Lager Beer
and carried on with the customary
dramatics. And did Hopkins "rise
to the utmost heights ?" Well, look
at the score next day.
Jake Miller of '22, slightly under
the weather and hunting for a
"short fellow who called him
names," was called upon by popular
demand to give his little contribution to the evening. Warfield and
the other cheer leaders led the
cheering to the accompaniment of
one, or possibly two, fingered "seek
and find" on the piano.
But all things come to an end
and even Varsity Club parties are
no exception. After frenzied class
yells, the classes of '20 up being
most represented, the members went
home—presumably.
This smoker was begun last year
and it will be held as an annual
affair on the night before the Maryland game each year.

OF KESSLERS' KICK
RESULTS IN JAY VICTORY

JAYS LOSE EIGHT
BY GRADUATION
Eight of the Jay gridders
who played in the Maryland
game have participated in their
last football game at Hopkins.
With the exception of Kegan,
the entire line will be lost by
graduation at the end of this
year. Lawrence and Pindell
of the backfield also will not
return to the University.
Maryland, on the other
hand, will lose only five regulars. Adams, Zulich, Thomas,
Linkous and Captain Bafford
will not return to College
Park next year. Augie Roberts, who played a sensational
game at halfback, still has two
more years of college football.

0. K. D. to Announce
Pledges Thursday
Honorary Activities Society To Take
Charge of Assembly

Omicron Delta Kappa will take
charge of this Thursday's assembly.
The student body will witness the
public initiation of the flew men
chosen at the fall elections this year.
Dean Joseph S. Ames will be the
principal speaker. In the eve" ,g
the customary private initiation and
banquet will be held at the Southern Hotel. Walter B. Swindell, Jr.,
will preside as toast-master.
0. D. K. is a national honor society for men who distinguish themselves in the various branches of
college activities. It is a means of
recognition and reward for those
who have given unsparingly of their
time and effort and who have benefited the university. I. Evans Rodgers is president this year.

attempted to drop-kick the point

Strader opened a hole in the right
side of the line and. stellar Benny
Boynton tore through and cornered
the ball before it had gone three feet
from Kess1er's toe. With a onepoint lead the Blue team braced up

of the fourth quarter, when it called
upon an unlooked-for and almost
an undreamed-of reserve strength,
which resulted in a drive down the
field to the Terrapins' four-yard
line. Just as the stands were sensing another score, the whistle blew,
the game was ended and Hopkins
had achieved what had been its goal
for twelve years.

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS

95-J

'ION
es

Harvard has challenged Yale to
a "battle of culture," thus inaugurating something new in the field of
intercollegiate activity. Harvard
suggests the meeting of teams of
ten men before a body of judges,
to contest the superiority of college
men in the realms of the erudite.
In order to obviate all chance of
t'cramming" before such a contest,
the ten men cannot be licked until
very shortly before the time the
teams meet. If this idea survives
the ridicule it is bound to receive,
Harvard will have launched a
Worthy movement toward making
• colleges further fulfill their original
purpose.
*

NG

aRY

;T.

*

The idea of the waste of a college education, as talked about by
our eminent Dr. Mitchell some time
ago, seems to be very contagious.
Grbizt W. Van Salm, super-intellectual at Lafayette and winner of
many oratorical pri,s'es; asks the Lafayette undergraduates in a recent
assembly: "College! - What's the
Use?" He puts his answer much
more mildly than the fiery Dr.
Mitchell. "College did nothing
more than waste four years of my
life." And yet, college enrollments
are growing everywhere. What
silly sots are we poor collegians!

John Van Druten, who produced
a Play at the Playshop last year,
recently delivered a lecture at Lafayette on "Making a Play." This
noted English playwright was received at Lafayette bjran enthusiastic group, and lectured to a very
large audience. He spoke of the
new ideas and technique of writing
Plays, and many other interesting
features of the playwright's life.
Van Druten's personality and interesting topic won for him the praise
of Lafayette's dramatists, just as he
wan praise here last year.
* * * * *
Two students at the City College of New York have been suspended indefinitely for agitation
.against compulsory military training. Military training at this college has been a disputed quesfon
for a number of years. A vote
taken two years ago; following extraordinarv agitation, showed the
students to be against the compulsory training by a tremendous malority. Parents of the boys were
also greatly against it. Then for
two years no more was heard on
the subject. But now, another crisis
has come. Why not, as the Daily
:rincetonian advocates in reviewing the situation, "make military
training a non-compulsory course?"
Certainly, it works pretty well here
at Hopkins.

lithorities.
This action was taken
In order to overcome carelessness in
money matters and to check up on
unpaid bills, which have from time
tO time

annoyance.

HOPKINS HOLDS EARLY LEAD TO
DEFEAT MARYLAND BY ONE POINT

M

(Continued from page 1, column 5.)

land exchanged the kick and after
two passes, Lyons to Boynton and
then to Caplan, the b01 was on the
5-yard line. A third_ pass was
grounded over the goal line and
the ball was brought out to Maryland's 20-yard line.
Another exchange of punts, a
few line plays and the quarter ended
with the ball in Hopkins' possession. Score at end of quarter: Hopkins 7—Maryland 0.
The second quarter began with
Hopkins completing two passes; the
second a long one to Captain Mallonee which put the ball on Maryland's 8 yard line. Two line plays
and Lawrence dived across .the goal
for the second score. Again Caplan booted the ball over the bar,
with the splendid co-operafon of
Lyons, for the extra point.
Roberts Nearly Scores

Maryland received the kick-off
and Roberts, Terrapin back-field
star, then proceeded to furnish one
of the most thrilling incidents of
the game when, with almost perfect
interference, he broke away and
looked as though he would make a
touchdown until he was finally
brought down by Mallonee and
Lyons.
The game see-sawed back and
forth, neither team having much
the better of it except in the k!cking department, where every exchange of punts netted Hopkins
anywhere from 5 to 20 yards. The
half, an all-Hopkins half, ended
with the score: Hopkins 14—Maryland 0.
What "Curly" Byrd lacked in
generalship in sending his second
team on the field to be scored upon
so easily in the first quarter and
then having his nervous and cold
first-string men fa:1 to stop the
swift-moving Hopkins machine, he
almost made up by injecting a marvelous amount of fight into his
players during the rest between
halves, for the third quarter was as
much an "all-Maryland" affair as
the first half had been an all-Hopkins one.

Esso

Maryland ran through the line,
around the end and heaved passes
until they took the ball over for
their first score. Kessler dropkicked the extra point. After the
first taste of blood Maryland was
not to be stopped, and after two
first downs a pass netted the Terrapins 20 yards and put the ball on
the Jays' 22-yard line. Another
first down and the quarter was over,
with the ball on Hopkins' 3-yard
line. Score at end of third quarter,
Hopkins 14—Maryland 7.
Two plays were all that were
needed to take the ball the necessary 3 yards, but when Kessler went
back to kick, the ball had hardly
left his toe before Boynton, who
had replaced Pindell in the backfield, Houston filling his place at
end, was on him and the ball was
grounded. From that point on
Hopkins began to play better and
better, so that by the end of the
game the ball was on Maryland's
4 yard line.
The game was a victory of one
wonderfully playing team over another. Neither team lost one ounce
of fight—it was just Hopkins' day
and the Big Blue team seized its
opportunity to win a glorious victory.

1927 JUNE WEEK
DEFICIT MADE UP
The 1927 June Week Committee has made up its deficit.
The money cleared on the
dance at the Maryland Casualty after the Maryland-Hopkins game made up the needed
money and more besides. Total
gate receipts to date are
$765.20. That means that
there were 380 couples present. The expenses for the hall
and orchestra amounted to
$250, leaving a balance of
$515.20. The committee owed
the University a note of $401.
The money made on the dance
paid that off and left a remainder of $114.20, which will
be turned over to the Student
Activities Council.

Class Lacrosse
Game Thursday

-takui

Large Crowd Expected To Attend
Frosh-Soph Battle.

Four more days will decide
whether or not the freshmen don
their regalia until Christmas.
Thursday they clash with the sophomores in lacrosse and Saturday
in football and class rush.
In lacrosse a few freshmen have
been practicing faithfully, under the
leadersh:p of Norman Robinson,
ex-captain of the Blue Jay stickwielders, for several weeks.
As this is the first year that lacrosse has been substituted for
baseball, there should be a crowd
to witness the inauguration of this
sport as a freshman-sophomore contest.
Saturday's scrimmage should
abound in thrills. Sadder and
wiser after their first two defeats,
the frosh are determined to beat
the sophs, in spite of the fact that
the latter team has continually won
in the past.
Sophomore football equipment
was distributed yesterday. George
Darley, who is coaching the secondyear men, s endeavoring to mould
a shifty eleven.
Robinson will officiate at the la—
crosse match, while Mallonee will
officiate at the football game. As
the.frosh have won the track meet,
one more victory for them will
cause the abolishment of green ties,
black socks and frosh buttons.
